articles.headline: Gregg Ends Bid for Commerce Job
articles.snippet: Senator Judd Gregg said there were “irresolvable conflicts” between him and the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: Senator Judd Gregg said there were “irresolvable conflicts” between him and the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire abruptly withdrew Thursday as the nominee for commerce secretary, saying he had “irresolvable conflicts” with President Obama over his economic stimulus plan and a concern over what many fellow Republicans believe is the politicization of the 2010 census.

articles.headline: Ex-G.M. Workers Try to Reboot Their Lives
articles.snippet: Their $28-an-hour jobs gone, laid-off workers from a plant in Wisconsin are trying to reinvent themselves.
articles.abstract: Their $28-an-hour jobs gone, laid-off workers from a plant in Wisconsin are trying to reinvent themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: JANESVILLE, Wis.— Kevin Corkhill grew up in a time and place where manufacturing was king. But ever since he was laid off from the gargantuan General Motors plant here, Mr. Corkhill seems bewildered by what the future holds.

articles.headline: U.S. Agents Scrutinize Texas Firm
articles.snippet: Authorities wonder whether the high yields offered by Stanford Financial are simply too good to be true.
articles.abstract: Authorities wonder whether the high yields offered by Stanford Financial are simply too good to be true.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, R. Allen Stanford, a flamboyant Texas billionaire, richly rewarded the well-heeled clients of his private investment empire.

articles.headline: In Japan’s Stagnant Decade, Cautionary Tales for America
articles.snippet: Some students of Japan’s lost decade say they see the United States making familiar mistakes.
articles.abstract: Some students of Japan’s lost decade say they see the United States making familiar mistakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  The Obama administration is committing huge sums of money to rescuing banks, but the veterans of Japan’s banking crisis have three words for the Americans: more money, faster.

articles.headline: Rescue Plan for Housing in the Works
articles.snippet: The administration is developing a standardized way to fix the mortgages of people near foreclosure.
articles.abstract: The administration is developing a standardized way to fix the mortgages of people near foreclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is trying to come up with a standardized approach for using taxpayer money to modify the mortgages of people in danger of losing their homes, officials said on Thursday.

articles.headline: Sensors Help Keep the Elderly Safe, and at Home
articles.snippet: New technologies help older people to live alone and avoid trips to hospitals or nursing homes.
articles.abstract: New technologies help older people to live alone and avoid trips to hospitals or nursing homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Increasingly, many older people who live alone are not truly alone. They are being watched by a flurry of new technologies designed to enable them to live independently and avoid expensive trips to the emergency room or nursing homes.

articles.headline: Ailing Banks May Require More Aid to Keep Solvent
articles.snippet: Experts say the situation at some of the nation’s banks demands a more direct government role than in the plan outlined this week.
articles.abstract: Experts say the situation at some of the nation’s banks demands a more direct government role than in the plan outlined this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s large banks, according to economists and other finance experts, are like dead men walking.

articles.headline: What’s in the Stimulus Bill for You
articles.snippet: Most of us will be able to use at least one of the tax breaks and handouts included in the proposed stimulus bill.
articles.abstract: Most of us will be able to use at least one of the tax breaks and handouts included in the proposed stimulus bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: All the talk the last couple of days about the stimulus bill was about compromise and slimming down. What is left, though, is a huge spending bill, with well over $100 billion in tax breaks and handouts for individuals.

articles.headline: Starting at Home, Iran’s Women Fight for Rights
articles.snippet: Iranian women are showing growing determination to achieve equal status in this conservative Muslim country.
articles.abstract: Iranian women are showing growing determination to achieve equal status in this conservative Muslim country.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  In a year of marriage, Razieh Qassemi, 19, says she was beaten repeatedly by her husband and his father. Her husband, she says, is addicted to methamphetamine and has threatened to marry another woman to “torture” her.
